dcterms:creator: Stan Wagon
dcterms:description: The Banach–Tarski paradox is a theorem in set-theoretic geometry that states that it is possible to decompose a solid ball into a finite number of non-overlapping pieces and reassemble them into two solid balls identical to the original.
dcterms:title: Banach–Tarski Paradox

dcterms:creator: Vladimir Vovk
dcterms:description: The Dubins–Schwarz theorem provides a framework for continuous-time trading without the need for probability measures, focusing on the emergence of probability in trading strategies.
dcterms:title: Dubins–Schwarz theorem

dcterms:creator: Christopher S. Hardin
Alan D. Taylor
dcterms:description: Hardin and Taylor's work on hat puzzles explores the connection between the Axiom of Choice and predicting future events, providing insights into decision-making processes.
dcterms:title: Hardin and Taylor’s work on hat puzzles

dcterms:creator: Nicolas Perkowski
David J. Pr¨omel
dcterms:description: Perkowski and Pr¨omel's definition of pathwise stochastic integrals provides a framework for model-free finance, allowing for the analysis of financial processes without relying on traditional probabilistic models.
dcterms:title: Perkowski and Pr¨omel’s definition

dcterms:description: Ockham prediction systems are frameworks that utilize the Axiom of Choice to make predictions about future events based on past observations, often applied in financial contexts.
dcterms:title: Ockham prediction systems
